comments:
Your code snippet looks ok.  At what point is the path becoming corrupt? Is the
temporary project created in the right place? I.e., is the .project file created
at "/tmp/sclmawb/.project"? If you print out the value of projectPath in your
snippet, what does it look like? Another way to create the path would be:

new Path(TEMP_DIR).append("sclmawb")

But it should end up with the same result either way.

We tried doing as you suggested, but get an error with the text:
"The project description file (.project) for sclmawb is missing. This
file contains important information about the project.  The project will not
function properly until this file is restored."

Interestingly, no .project was created in /tmp/sclmawb.

You'll have to debug this more yourself.  I see nothing wrong with the snippet
you provide... Does project.create succeed?  Is the directory /tmp/sclmawb/ even
created?  Do you have the appropriate permissions and is there sufficient disk
space?

We have certainly seen some inconsistent behavior.

The create project does succeed and /tmp/sclmawb is created.  Most of the time
there is no .project file.

The file system containing /tmp has 29GB available space and there are no 
permissions problems.

I have found the cause of the problem.

On Linux, the system property java.io.tmpdir is set to /tmp.

On other UNIX platforms it is set to /tmp/.

Invoking eclipse eclipse -vmargs -Djava.io.tmpdir=/tmp/ fixed the problem.

This doesn't explain it for me.  Your snippet does this:

Path(TEMP_DIR + File.separator + "sclmawb")

So even if TEMP_DIR did not have a separator, you are adding one.  Were you not
doing this consistently?

The fact that java.io.tmpdir was set to /tmp/ on other platforms was hiding
a bug in our code which I have fixed.

However, we are puzzled as to why java.io/tmpdir has a value with a trailing /
on some platforms and not others.

Unfortunately those system properties are provided by the VM, and typically
aren't carefully specified.  Any particular VM vendor, version, or platform can
return a different result. The only advice I can give is to use the Eclipse
IPath and Path objects, which automatically add slashes when needed, collapse
duplicate slashes, etc... it helps avoid some of the pain of manipulating file
system paths in a platform independent way.
